title: Acoustical Variables in Open Planning
container-title: The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America
items.abstract: <jats:p>The articulation index (AI) has been widely accepted as an objective measure of environments for speech communication and/or privacy. It quantifies speech intelligibility in terms of the S/N ratio on a scale extending from 0 to 1. While more experimentation is required to verify the subjective equivalent of any given AI, the AI itself can be calculated and hence predicted. It has been found that in buildings without complete floor-to-ceiling partitions, the AI changes drastically with the following variables: speech effort, speaker orientation, background noise, speaker-to-listener distance, and barrier attenuation (if present and unflanked). This paper discusses the relative effect of these variables on the AI, and thus demonstrates the importance of each parameter when designing open-plan facilities.</jats:p>

title: Planning for the handling of radiation accidents
Book Review: New Product Planning
DECOMPOSITION OF PLANNING SYSTEMS
items.abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>While Dantzig and Wolfe have formulated the decomposition algorithm as a computational device, it was subsequently recognized that the principle underlying the algorithm may also be utilized by a planning system to achieve a centralized planning within the framework of a decentralized organizational structure. This paper illustrates the workings of such a planning system and, at the same time, explores some of the problems connected with its actual implementation. The planning system under the study is called the decomposed planning system in order to distinguish it from either the centralized planning or the decentralized planning.</jats:p>

ADVANCE PLANNING SUCCESS IN CHICAGO
items.abstract: <jats:p>The need for advance planning in water facilities prompted the city of Chicago to conduct a series of studies to enable them to carry out the planning before the need for an increase in facilities arose, instead of after. This paper outlines the probable construction costs, based on 1969 price levels, and details the steps taken in the planning.</jats:p>

Society’s Responsibility to Medicine: Government as a Catalyst in the Planning and Delivery of Total Health Care
items.abstract: <jats:p> The distinguished Guthrie Lecturers whom you have invited in past years have chosen to direct their remarks chiefly to the experiences of medical men whom history has marked for distinction. Many of those historical figures were contemporaries of Dr. Donald Guthrie and, in reviewing their significant work, light was shed on the circumstances under which he did his important work. I regret that I never knew Dr. Guthrie personally. However, Dr. Donald Balfour, Director of the Mayo Foundation, with whom I worked, knew him well and spoke often and with great admiration of this skillful surgeon and of his abilities as a leader of men. I count it an honor to speak to you tonight in memory of Dr. Guthrie. </jats:p>

title: SIMULATION ‐ DECISION AID IN PLANNING DESALTING APPLICATIONS<sup>1</sup>
container-title: JAWRA Journal of the American Water Resources Association
items.abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The difficulty and complexity in evaluating water resource problems is becoming more evident to management with each passing year. Decisions are required sooner, in more detail, with some background—and yet cost more to evolve. One potential method to arrive at solutions at least more rapidly and in more detail is via simu‐ lation. A manager may evaluate many alternative solutions to his problem—provided an evaluated simulation system is at his disposal.</jats:p><jats:p>One such system under development is a highly flexible computerized model system for evaluating real economic/technical applicability of desalting to a selected area. The Economic Evaluation Model System (EEMS) was initially conceived during 1968 and the first version was completed in 1969.</jats:p><jats:p>This system represents the combination of technical, environmental and economic functions into an interrelated system, which allows the user to examine a broad range of water related problems—oriented toward the applicability of desalting as an additional or alternative source of water.</jats:p><jats:p>The major thrust of the development of the system thus far, however, has been with the methodology involved and further refinements and extensions of the system are recognized and planned for in future research and development.</jats:p>
